Award.AwardTitle: Continuous Chromatography with Reactions for the Purification of Rare Earth Elements

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1403854
Wang
Purdue University

The project aims to develop new efficient and economical methods to produce compounds of rare earth elements (REEs), such as neodymium, Nd, praseodymium, Pr, and samarium, Sm. Such elements are widely used in many high-tech products, such as petroleum refining catalysts, phosphors in color television and flat panel displays, permanent magnets, and rechargeable batteries. They are in short supply in the US and need to be imported from China, which produces over 95% of the world's REE supply and plans to restrict exports. It is important for the US industry and national security to develop environmentally sustainable methods to increase domestic REE supply, while minimizing production costs.

The objective of this proposed project is to understand the fundamental concepts and generate the new data required to develop efficient continuous chromatography with reactions to replace the current extraction-based purification processes for REEs production. Systematic design and scale-up methods based on intrinsic adsorption and mass transfer parameters and dimensionless groups will be developed. The Standing Wave Design methods for continuous isocratic-elution systems without reactions will be extended to continuous systems with reactions. The design methods will be verified with rate model simulations and experimental data from three REEs (Pr, Nd, and Sm). The two purification methods (step-wise elution and displacement) will be integrated with capture chromatography in an efficient continuous process. A new six-zone continuous chromatography unit will be designed, built, and tested for the separation of Pr, Nd, and Sm. Both ligand-assisted stepwise elution and displacement chromatography will be tested using this new equipment. Both purification methods will be evaluated and compared with batch chromatography and tandem SMB for productivity, solvent usage, and separation costs. The results will have a major impact on managing the life cycles of REEs, while minimizing purification costs, solvent usage, waste production, and environmental impact. The design methods and the simulation tools developed in this project can be used to develop efficient continuous chromatography processes with reactions to produce other high-purity chemicals with high yield from complex mixtures.

The project will involve graduate and undergraduate students, and will lead to improved teaching materials. The results potentially will be used by industry for REE production and by other researchers for similar or different separations. The results will have a major impact on the production costs of fine chemicals, biochemicals, foods, and pharmaceuticals, which have multibillion dollar annual sales. The project will also impact teaching of separations and help transfer this new technology to industry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Rare earth elements (REEs) include the elements in the lanthanide series plus yttrium and scandium. They are essential for the functions of many electronics and high-technology products. They are the key ingredients (or ?vitamins?) of magnets, batteries, sensors, catalysts, phosphors, TV screens, cell phones, advanced jet engines, and missile guidance systems. A hybrid car, for example, has more than 30 pounds of REEs in its batteries and sensors. The demand of REEs has grown rapidly over the past two decades, but the production of REEs has been limited to a few countries. China currently controls over 90% of the global production of REEs. There has been no production of REEs in the US since the bankruptcy of Molycorp in 2015. The Chinese monopoly of the REEs production has serious geopolitical, economical, and national defense implications. Foreign manufacturers are making products in China because of favorable tax rates and stable, low-cost supplies of REEs. China is now making more than 40% of the key components of high-technology products in the world. Analysts have warned that if the current trend continues, China will have world-wide monopoly for making high-technology products by 2040.

The conventional methods of REEs production are based on extraction of REEs from ores. Mining, grinding, physical separation, magnetic separation, strong acid or base leaching, neutralization, and precipitation are required to obtain crude mixtures of REEs. The crudes are further purified using two-phase liquid-liquid extraction to produce individual REEs with high-purity. Since REEs have the same valence and little differences in size or other physical and chemical properties, more than 1,000 mixer-settler units in sequence or in parallel are needed to produce high-purity REEs from ores. The liquid-liquid extraction method has a low interfacial area per processing volume, and thus requires large amounts of solvents and extractants. About 2,000 tons of waste are produced for each ton of REE oxide produced. The generation of large amounts of hazardous waste is not environmentally sustainable. Since US has strict environmental regulations, US producers cannot use the conventional technologies to produce REEs and compete with China in the global market. This is a key reason that there is no REEs production in the US currently.

 We have developed in this NSF project new chromatography technologies for REE purification. Although conventional ion exchange resins or chromatography sorbents do not have sufficient selectivity for REEs, a ligand which have significant selectivity for REEs can be added in the mobile phase to achieve REE separations. We developed the first ligand-assisted elution (LAE) method for REE purification based on a robust inorganic adsorbent, titania. The results indicated that LAE can reduce the processing volume of liquid-liquid extraction by an order of magnitude and replace 1,000 or more mixer-settlers with a few chromatography columns.

We also studied the ligand-assisted displacement chromatography (LAD), and found that this method can have an order of magnitude higher productivity and ligand efficiency than the ligand-assisted elution method (LAE). The feasibility of LAD for the purification of three REEs was first demonstrated by Spedding and Powell in the 1950?s. The separation mechanisms of LAD were not well understood, no process models were developed, and no systematic design/optimization method were available in the literature. For these reasons, all the literature LAD processes were designed by trial and error. The separation of three REEs, for example, took three months to complete. For these reasons, LAD has not been developed for large scale production of REEs.

In this project, we developed the first detailed rate model simulations to elucidate the separation mechanisms in LAD. The simulations were verified with our own data and data from the literature. Furthermore, we developed a new design method, the constant-pattern design method, to achieve the highest sorbent productivity and ligand efficiency for a desired product purity and yield. The design method is robust, scalable, and requires no trial and error.  It provides the optimal operating conditions to meet the target yield and purity of one or multiple components for different crude mixtures and systems at any scale. The productivities achieved using this design method are about 840 times higher than the literature results with similar REE yields and purities. We also developed a continuous LAD process, which has the potential to reduce the processing volume of the liquid-liquid extraction by 100-fold and the amount of extractant by 25-fold. The 1,000 mixer-settler units can be replaced by a few chromatography columns. Most of the chemicals are safe and can be recycled. The new technologies are expected to reduce the capital expenses and chemical costs for REE purification by an order of magnitude. The new technologies have the potential to transform the $4B REE industry and to enable the US to be independent of foreign REE supplies.
